items.title: Add guard to TouchTracker to avoid unexpected behavior from multitouch gestures
items.body:
Currently, multitouch (e.g., two finger pinch) gestures trigger 'start', 'update' and 'end' events on the TouchSync. This places a large burden on the developer to parse event data in order to achieve expected behavior. This problem is exacerbated if the developer desires to have both a TouchSync and PinchSync attached to a surface. Take the example of a developer wanting to 'drag' an surface using the TouchSync and to scale it using the PinchSync. Every time the user pinches, both those touches are going to be piped into the TouchSync causing the surface to move in erratic ways. Every developer trying to implement this common case would need to parse the data.identifier in order to adjust for only one touch input. A simpler solution is to only have the TouchSync map to one finger gestures (and if a developer wants to move an item with a two finger gestures they can do so by using the data.center attribute passed through the PinchSync.)

This PR updates TouchTracker to:
1.) Only emit 'start'/'update' events if there is a single touch
2.) Only emit 'end' events if 'start' was previously triggered by a single touch.

items.title: InputSurface.getValue() returns blank regardless of contents
Smarter FastClick
items.body:
The current FastClick implementation matches events based on the event target. This doesn't work for my app because at the point of time the click event finally fires an animation has already played thus the click **event hits a different target** and it won't get canceled properly. I propose doing the matching based on the position. That's more reliable in the typical animation heavy famo.us app.

For those who have concerns that this isn't strict enough anymore, here's the deal: The worst thing that can happen is that the event for a legit click gets canceled that happened within the first 500ms after a touch in a only 70px wide box around it. This half second isn't even enough time to grab the mouse properly :)

items.title: Mouse & Touch Sync Velocity
items.body:
These three commits fix two problems. If desired, they can be split up and issued as separate pull requests.

##### Double eventing on MouseDrag 6d27f97 
If you had a mouse drag starting on an element, left the element, and passed over it again, it would trigger another mouseleave event. Without this fix, multiple event listeners would be attached to document.body, causing the event to be fired many times. 

##### Unstable Velocity 1e12fea & 6d3b38b
Previously, velocity was only the delta between the current frame and the last. This led to very inconsistent velocity values. By taking the delta from 10 frames back, the velocity values are much more stable. It also eliminates the possibility of receiving a random [0,0] velocity return, which was the main issue we ran into. 

Doing some pretty basic testing, and dragging as smoothly as possible in an upwards right angle, the average variability between each velocity delta is below. 
```js
With frame delay
0.5696997600166982% 
3.0226436369485223%
Without 
5.7359798910147836%
5.66135823561128 %
```

@michaelobriena

items.body: ...bution of pull request #137, consider further refactor of this._agents to a proper array

items.title: [Fix] Wrap Fast Click in Closure
items.body:
Currently fast click calls return if ```!window.CustomEvent```.  This caused no problems when we were only releasing using AMD, as this return was wrapped in closure, but it unfortunately breaks everything when the framework is run in Common.

This fix wraps all the code inside of fast click in a self executing function, making sure that the return doesn't make everything throw up.

items.body: We should only be emitting a change event on a primitive data type change. The event emitted in patch is redundant and could reduce performance.

items.title: A Draggable() Surface blocks input focus
Famo.us/Chrome Bug
items.body:
Hello,

I somehow have problems adding many modifiers/surfaces to a context in Chromium/Chrome. First thought I have a bug somewhere in my code but after hours of debugging and not finding anything wrong I realized that it works perfectly fine in Firefox.

I created a simplified version to reproduce the problem which can be seen here:
http://jsfiddle.net/janober/aLyfxzws/

If I run it in Firefox it displays me 1-20 like it should.
But if I run it in Chromium it just displays me: 9-20
In Chrome it also displays me 1-20 but makes problems as soon as I change the loop to a higher value. So from 20 to 40 for example. Then it suddenly just displays me 7-40. In Firefox I was not able to reproduce that problem at all.

Hope that is helpful and the bug can be fixed.

Just in case. I run Ubuntu 14.04 and use
Chromium: Version 36.0.1985.125 Ubuntu 14.04 (283153)
Chrome: Version 36.0.1985.143
Firefox: 31.0c

Thanks & blue skies

items.title: WallTransition: Problems with restitution
items.body:
Some quirks I noticed with restitution:

Converges although I expected it to bounce forever with the same height (`restitution: 1`):
```
var transition = { method: 'wall', period: 100, dampingRatio: 0, restitution: 1 }
```

But with period increased it does the opposite, it bounces higher and higher. I expected it to bounce forever with the same height (`restitution: 1`):
```
var transition = { method: 'wall', period: 1000, dampingRatio: 0, restitution: 1 }
```

And finally this one bounces, although I expected it to just stick to the wall once it reaches it (`restitution: 0`):
```
var transition = { method: 'wall', period: 300, dampingRatio: 0, restitution: 0 }
```

My demo ground was http://famo.us/university/famous-101/animating/7/ (simply changed it to WallTransition) with Chrome 35 on Mac OS 10.9.2.

Could it be that there is some mistake in the setup of the simulation?

items.title: moz, ms, and o vendor prefix support
items.body: Currently in famo.us there is only support for non-prefixed and webkit prefixes. To better support other browsers, there should be a central location where tests for vendor prefixes are done, then all methods that touch the DOM (in ElementOutput) can use that info.

items.title: [Feature request] add render controller events
items.body: It should be usefull for everybody to know the 'start' event to start some other animation in parallel, 'update' and 'end' events to synchronize those animations.

items.title: ElementAllocator#deallocate is trying to deallocate an element that hasn't been allocated
items.body:
I get this error, here is the stack trace. I can not provide you a reproducible example, because its very hard to reproduce and happens in a non-trivial application.

It looks like ContainerSurface has an element which hasn't been allocated using ElementAllocator. It tries to deallocate a Surface at the time where ElementAllocator#detachedNodes.div is empty.


Here is the stacktrace:

    TypeError: Cannot read property 'push' of undefined
        at ElementAllocator.deallocate (/code/dist/local/index.js:6261:18)
        at ContainerSurface.cleanup (/code/dist/local/index.js:8579:15)

        at Context.update (/code/dist/local/index.js:6077:16)

items.title: TransitionableTransform: Fix halt()
items.body: Each final state needs to be set to the current state after the transition has been halted. Otherwise the _final* states do not represent the actual final states, but the final states of the previous (unfinished) transformation. This results into unexpected behavior when doing a single transformation (e.g. rotation) on a halted TransitionableTransform that didn't update its final states, since the _buildFinal uses the _final* of each Transformation (which hasn't been updated).

items.title: GenericSync spitting out too many events

labels.name: Check if CLA is on record

items.body:
MenuButton.js: https://gist.github.com/StephanBijzitter/067cb23d2edb11585d65
Snippet for menu visibility: https://gist.github.com/StephanBijzitter/3cd05070ce21339800ef
Based on: http://famousco.de/2014/07/material-designish-button-animation/

Expected behaviour depends on the state of the app: the page it is on and whether the menu is open or closed.

To give consistency to this report I will define the following:
Press: any event that indicates either a touch start or mouse press event;
Release: any event that indicates either a touch end or mouse release event;
Hold: a period of 600 milliseconds or more between press and release.
Click: a period less than 600 milliseconds between press and release.

The button has two states:
0: Hamburger (menu) icon
1: Back arrow

When the state is 0 and the user clicks or holds the button, open the menu if it is closed or close the menu if it is open.
When the state is 1 and the user clicks the button, go back to the parent page of the current page.
When the state is 1 and the user holds the button, change state temporarily to 0 and show the menu.
*) The user then closes the menu by pressing or holding the button once again, reverting its icon back to 1 in the process.

On computers without touch screens, this works as expected. On some mobile phones, this works as expected. Sadly, not on all phones.

On a test Huawei, when clicking the icon with state 0, the menu shows and instead of staying visible, it hides itself. The same behaviour occurs when holding the icon with state 1. This leads me to believe that it receives multiple events. The first of these would cause the menu to open, and the second would cause it to close.

So I tested this theory and commented out the mouse sync from the generic sync and as I suspected, the Huawei had no more issues. I have also tested this on the iOS Simulator, which gave me the exact same behaviour.

It therefore seems that on some phones, both mouse and touch events are emitted from a generic sync if the user touches the screen.

items.title: scrollView index is wrong
items.body:
I have a horizontal scrollview
sending `goToNextPage()` will go through all the panels
but `goToPreviousPage()` gets stuck on the 1st (not zero index) panel. 
seems like a zero index bug?

afaik there's no public API to check the current page/panel. 
but i am using
```
    @scrollview.on 'pageChange', (e) =>
      p = @scrollview._node.index
      console.log('pageChange', p, e)
```

```
   0 > 1 > 2 > 3   # first time is ok
   3 < 1 < 0
   0 > 2 > 3
```

given all the hoopla around Carousel demos at the famous meetup the other night, i would have thought horizontal carousel type scrolling code was safe from these type of issues. is there another private branch that is being used for those?

also, is there any way to set a specific page num, or a better way than peeking at `_node` (=private?) properties?

items.title: Infinite expansion bug
items.body:
(as per our conversation in-office)

A surface (or any ElementOutput) with no defined size within a context will infinitely expand on each Engine tick, even if the context has a defined size.

cc @michaelobriena

items.title: Move all DOM touching to ElementOutput
items.body:
(as per our conversation in-office)

ElementOutput should be the central place in the code where the DOM is being touched. Currently perspective is being handled in Context, size is being handled in Surface, etc.

By moving everything to one place we improve organization and also fix size/perspective on non-surface ElementOutputs. Currently setSize does nothing unless it is a surface which is a huge blocker for integration with lower level systems.

items.title: iOS minimal-ui: wrong landscape height
items.body:
With iOS 7.1 we got minimal-ui in Safari
``` html
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1, user-scalable=no, minimal-ui">
```

In landscape mode I get a wrong window size. The height is too small. Any idea what causes that?

[Venture Beat App](http://1799ac.html5.accept.appmachine.com) (Extracted URL from [YouTube Video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Qi-WXWx_Xo)) My own app has the same problem.
